column3: Legend of the Mulata de Córdoba
column5: A mysterious and eternally youthful woman known as La Mulata was reputed to possess supernatural powers, allowing her to be in multiple places simultaneously and escape from this location - once an Inquisition prison. Despite her philanthropic deeds, she was said to have connections with the devil, and following her miraculous escape, she was never seen again. The legend suggests that after La Mulata was accused of witchcraft and imprisoned, she conjured a charcoal ship on her cell wall and sailed into freedom.

The Rollright Stones, situated on a spur of the Cotswold hills, are said to be remnants of a king and his army who were transformed into stone by a witch, as they were about to conquer England but were thwarted by treachery and magic. The king became the "King Stone, " while his five conspiring knights turned into 'Whispering Knights, ' and his soldiers into a stone circle, all surrounded by elder trees believed to be linked to the witch's curse.

column3: The Witch of Wookey and the Monk's Exorcism
column5: The Witch of Wookey, known for her malice driven by rejection, blighted the crops and sowed discord with the help of imps until a brave monk from Glastonbury Abbey confronted and petrified her, neutralizing the threat she posed to Somersetshire. To this day, visitors can see her petrified form in Wookey Hole, a testament to the monk's exorcism, while exploring the historic and scenic surroundings of Wells and Glastonbury.

column3: The Legend of the Four Halls
column5: In the hamlet of Ellenglaze, near Perran Bay, a young Lord builds a fourth hall, undeterred by warnings of the sands that previously consumed the area, but after a fierce storm and the threat of the sands approaching, his bride persuades him to spare an old witch, prompting a miraculous stream that saves the hall. This stream, created by tears from a kiss given by the bride to the old woman, prevents the sands from advancing, ensuring the safety of Ellenglaze as long as it continues to flow.

column3: Witches Selling Themselves to the Devil
column5: In Cardiganshire, it was believed that some old women became witches by giving Communion bread to the Devil after walking around Llanddewi Brefi Church. Another tale from North Pembrokeshire tells of a man who gained bewitching powers by secretly feeding his Communion bread to a dog, symbolizing his pact with the Devil.

A woman in Llangwyryfon, suspected of being a witch, was believed to have caused another woman's illness after the latter refused to deliver leather for her and her shoemaker husband. The sick woman's son consulted a conjurer who predicted the witch's visit, resulting in the mother's swift recovery upon the suspected witch's arrival and apology.

column3: A Farmer's Daughter Bewitched for Refusing Alms
column5: In Walton East, Pembrokeshire, a young woman was sick for fifteen years after being bewitched by an old woman she had refused alms to. Only after the death of the supposed witch did the young woman recover and eventually go on to live a happy life as a farmer's wife.

column3: Men Witched by an Old Lledrod Hag
column5: Thomas Lewis of Garthfawr, suffering from severe pain believed to be caused by an old witch, miraculously recovered after a wise man was consulted. In another instance, after Rhys Rhys forced the witch to undo her spell on churned milk, she cursed him instead, resulting in his permanent ill health.

In the village of Mathry, Pembrokeshire, there was a known witch who was accused of casting spells on cattle, causing them to act strangely. After a farmer's cows were found unable to stand, he confronted the suspected witch, who reversed the spell by touching each cow, which then promptly returned to normal.

column3: Sheep Killed by an Old Witch
column5: An old witch living near Ystrad Meurig requested a shepherd to gift her a lamb, which he refused. In retaliation, she cursed the shepherd, resulting in the mysterious death of the lamb and its mother, attributed to her witchcraft.

During the launch of H.M. Ship 'Cæsar' at Pembroke Dock, an old woman named Betty Foggy, believed to have witching powers, was barred from joining the gentry and others in the grandstand by the police. Angry, she shouted that the ship wouldn't go off, and although initially ignored, 'Cæsar' stalled during launch as Betty had predicted, reinforcing local beliefs in her powers.

A young farmer in Llandilo, Carmarthenshire, suffered ill-fortune after a broken engagement, suspecting his ex-fiancée, believed to be a witch, was to blame. Upon consulting a local wizard, he was advised to bury a charmed paper under his farmyard gate-post, and following this advice, his misfortunes ceased.

In Cilcwm, Carmarthenshire, an old blacksmith named Mr. Theophilus recounted how his mother's cattle were under a witch's spell, causing them not to graze on their own farm's grass but to thrive on others'. After consulting the Wizard of Cwrt-y-Cadno, she performed a ritual involving a mountain ash and was able to identify the enemy responsible, successfully breaking the spell.

A farmer from Swyddffynon managed to incapacitate a witch riding behind him by drawing blood from her arm with a pocket-knife. As a result of this action, the witch was unable to continue her malevolent activities.

column3: A Witch Who Appeared in the Form of a Hare Every Morning to a Servant Maid at Milking Time
column5: A servant maid in Pontfaen, while milking cows, was repeatedly disturbed by an old witch who appeared as a hare each morning. Her master wounded the hare with his gun, and later, the witch named Maggie was found bedridden with a sore leg from the encounter.

column3: A Witch in the Form of a Hare Hunted by a Pembrokeshire Squire's Hounds
column5: The Squire of Llanstinan, persistent in his hunts, repeatedly failed to catch a hare, which he and the villagers suspected was a witch in disguise. Despite using a horse and dog of the same color, the hare escaped yet again, revealing itself as an old woman upon being cornered in a cottage.

column3: A Witch in the Form of a Hare Hunted in Cardiganshire
column5: Major Brooks of Llanarth repeatedly attempted to hunt a hare that displayed unusual cunning by eluding and even attacking his hounds, leading locals to suspect it was an old witch in disguise. Similarly, in Cilcwm, tales surfaced of Peggy Abercamles and her brother Will transforming into hares and running through the night.

column3: The Familiar Spirit of a Witch Shot in the Form of a Hare
column5: In Llanfihangel Genau'r Glyn, a man shot a hare believed to be the familiar spirit of a local witch using a silver coin. The witch, who was at home at the time, simultaneously fell into a tub, wounded and bleeding, suggesting a mystical connection with the familiar hare.

Before Carrigogunnel Castle rose, the monstrous hag Grana terrorized the land, luring travelers to doom with an enchanted candle whose light proved fatal by dawn. Her grotesque appearance and deadly pastime emptied the countryside and earned the rock its fearful title, “The Rock of the Candle.”

The legend of Kebokwe tells of a witch who was thrown from the execution rocks near Molepolole but survived through her magic, forever marking the cave with dark spiritual power. Later, David Livingstone used the same cave to demonstrate the triumph of faith over superstition, convincing Chief Sechele I to embrace Christianity.
According to local legend, a witch cursed the village of Niamawi after being denied water, causing a volcanic eruption that destroyed the town and left behind the mysterious “bottomless” lake.
Local lore from Easington tells of a hare that outwitted hunters and hounds until it limped into a cottage—only for the men to find not a hare, but an old woman binding a wounded heel.

Crazy Kate was a reclusive villager rumored to be a witch, said to slip away at night to the circular earthworks of Manwar Ings to take instruction from the Devil. When the locals finally confronted her there, a mysterious rider spirited her away, after which she vanished and her cottage was burned to the ground.

A witch named Old Meg plagued the countryside until a hero mounted a blind horse called Byard and fought her; in the struggle Byard made a famous great leap (or several) that killed the witch. The hamlet now called Byard’s Leap takes its very name from that legendary bound, still remembered by the marked hoofprints

As a Roman centurion rode toward Lincoln’s Newport Arch, his horse stopped dead; when he idly knotted a blade of grass and tossed it aside, it turned into a witch trussed up like a bundle, nose and limbs askew. With the spell broken, the horse moved on and the strange witch vanished, ending a tale that feels like the fragment of a much longer story

Witches steal a noble family’s baby to boil for charms, and blustering Billy Shuffler swears he’ll save the child—only to lose his nerve while the real heroes rescue the boy and capture horses from the witches’ cave. Forced to ride one, Billy is chased across Dunston Beck until his mount collapses and the witches reclaim it, leaving Shuffler to be fished out later and suitably humbled

Fan o’ the Fens, a striking girl from near Louth, is branded a witch after strange happenings—a chattering magpie, a sweetheart swollen by sorcery, and a neighbour cured only after a snake is lured from his belly. Suspected of Devil-worship on the marsh, she’s tried, survives mob justice at the river, and finally vanishes, leaving only witch-tales and whispers behind

A witch near Tetford was said to slip through a hole in her cottage and take the form of a hare, cursing neighbours until a hunter shot the hare and she was later found wounded at home. In some versions she dies, and in others she recovers, while related tales link her to bewitching relatives and to a charm that heals her after being shot as a hare

A witch’s ghost was said to haunt Pilford Bridge and shove passers-by into the water. Three parsons confronted the spirit, fed it a live cockerel, and trapped it in an iron pot that was buried so it could harm no more

Old Mother Nightshade gives lovesick John Culpepper enchanted sweetmeats and lures him back after three days, where she binds him and transforms into a wolf. She kills him and escapes before the villagers arrive, leaving only the prints of a wolf behind

Cleethorpes was long nicknamed “Meg’s Island, ” and its residents called “Meggies, ” supposedly because the area was once an isolated island and perhaps home to a lone woman named Meg—a figure some later imagined as a witch. The tale survives as an origin-legend for the town’s nickname, though no one knows the real reas
